column1: Tarhuna wa Msalata (Tarhuna and Msallata) was a district of Libya until 2007. Between 1988 and 1995 there existed the Tarhuna District
column2: which became Tarhuna wa Msalata between 2001 and 2007. It consisted of twenty-six Basic People's Congresses
column4: and its capital was Tarhuna.  In the 2007 administrative reorganization the territory formerly in Tarhuna wa Msalata was transferred to Murqub District.The rural population in Tarhuna is one of the largest in western Libya
column5: with a population density exceeding 50/km².Tarhuna was one of the leading resistance centres (with Misrata) to the Italian occupation of 1911.

column1: There are many archaeological remains in the Tarhuna region. However
column2: these remains are extremely dispersed over most parts of the plateau
column3: as is always in the case of hinterland of any significant ancient city. Another interesting point is that the Jebel Tarhuna was a boundary land between two important ancient coastal centres
column4: Leptis Magna and Oea. It is possible that this ancient reality may be reflected in settlement patterning. For Leptis Magna
column5: like many other cities in the Roman world
column6: the city was an integral part with its surrounding territory and its hinterland. Not all resources and items needed at the city could be obtained locally and from an early date Leptis Magna imported artefacts and other goods from through the Mediterranean. Certainly
column7: these artifacts and goods must be spread in the countryside and were not only distributed at the urban centre.

column1: The archaeological sites of the Tarhuna region were first reported in the nineteenth century by Heinrich Barth and Edwin Von Bary
column2: who visited them in 1849 and 1875 respectively. Both these pioneers gave a summary description of some ancient sites on the plateau
column3: which attracted attention of the late nineteenth and early twentieth century’s travellers and scholars. During the years 1895-6 H. Swainson Cowper visited the Tarhuna plateau and examined in considerable detail more than eighty ancient sites (Cowper 1897). Although he interpreted these sites as prehistoric monuments of religious character (Senams)
column4: his work constitutes a significant pioneer survey. It brought to light the archaeological importance of the Tarhuna region as a zone of intensive olive-cultivation during the classical period. Tarhuna Gebel was the area partly surveyed by Goodchild (1951)
column5: who had examined a number of ancient sites
column6: specially his excavation in the sanctuary of Ammon at Ras El-Haddagia
column7: and the villa and pottery-kilns at Ain Scersciara (Goodchild 1951: 43-77).

column1: At the same time (1949-51) Oates carried out much comprehensive archaeological survey in the area over some 300 square kilometres around Gas red-Daun at the eastern part of the Tarhuna Plateau. By three seasons of work
column2: he revealed a distribution of more than 100 sites
column3: which chronologically extended from the first century to the fifth century AD (Oates 1953). During the mid-nineteenth century
column4: the first century BCE pottery was little-known. However
column5: the Oates’ sites consist for the most part of varying size of farms associated with their water control and supply works
column6: which represent the key to their regional specialization.

column1: The Ottoman conquest started in 1530s and ruled until 1911.

column1: Battle of El-Shqiqa: a memorial of the battle was erected on the site of the execution of its hero Ali Swidan Alhatmy in the city centre of Tarhuna
